page.title: 02LOCAL HISTORY 2
page.content: rebuild the Church after fire by granting an Indulgence to anyone who gave money to the Building Fund. In 1542, a charter from Henry Vlll established a Saturday market and an annual fair on the Feast of the Assumption, so a Market Hall was built in the High Street.By the 17th. century the town had declined; but in the 19th. century the Grand Union Canal revived it.The County Police Force arrived here in 1846 (3 constables at Rickmansworth, 3 at Mill End and 2 at Batchworth): street lighting in 1852: the railway from Watford by 1862, and the Metropolitan Railway in 1887. A traveller by the first train said that "there were not more than 12 cottages after leaving Pinner" and described Rickmansworth as "a straggling street".
